quoteFirst: Either you ought to order another or hook it.' He braved it for several more ages, then paid, and went; and still it was only
quoteLast: . All mundane phenomena were inexplicably contorted that night. As he was passing the end of the short street which contains the stage-door of Prince's Theatre, a man, standing at the door on the lookout, hailed him loudly.
title: A Great Man: A Frolic

quoteFirst: On the 21st of August, 1919, you are Sergeant Stuart sent out in charge of a contact patrol from the 99th Infantry acting as outpost of the 32d Brigade. After hard work during which you are nearly captured at the cemetery near Henderson Meeting House, you arrive with your patrol, at
quoteTime: ten minutes to nine in the evening
quoteLast: , at 601 just west of Hunterstown. A regiment of the enemy’s infantry has been defeated by your troops during the day and it is your duty to find out what you can about the enemy’s whereabouts and intentions.
title: The English of military communications
author: Ganoe, William Addleman, 1881-1966

quoteLast: , the last men of the entire party had returned to the Hohlweg and went back to their dug-outs.

quoteLast: , Neale lighted a cigarette, put on his hat, and strolled slowly across the Market-Place. Although he knew every single one of its cobblestones, every shop window, every landmark in it, that queer old square always fascinated him. It was a bit of old England.
title: The Chestermarke Instinct
author: Fletcher, J. S. (Joseph Smith), 1863-1935

quoteFirst: Under rising moon enemy's ships were now seen approaching, and as _Glasgow_ could render _Monmouth_ no assistance, she proceeded at full speed to avoid destruction.

quoteLast: , when we will take our positions across this table; as you--er--happily express it, "face to face." As the clock strikes the hour, we will fire on the second stroke.
